Maryland has implemented several policies in recent years to address the state's unique healthcare challenges. Here are some of them:

1. Health insurance marketplace - Maryland operates its own health insurance marketplace (also known as the Maryland Health Connection) where residents can compare and purchase health insurance plans, including Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP).

2. All-payer model - Maryland is the only state in the country that has an all-payer healthcare model, which means that hospitals receive the same payments from all insurers, including Medicare and Medicaid. This model aims to control healthcare costs and improve the quality of care.

3. Prescription drug affordability board - In 2019, Maryland established a Prescription Drug Affordability Board to examine and set upper payment limits for certain high-cost prescription drugs. The board's goal is to make prescription drugs more affordable for Maryland residents.

4. Behavioral health initiatives - Maryland has implemented several initiatives to address the state's behavioral health challenges, including increased funding for mental health services, addiction treatment, and suicide prevention programs.
